descriptionSet.description: On this image, the figure of female person, also known as Bharat Mata or Mother India holding a tricolour flag and standing on the southern peak of the subcontinent can be seen as well as four heads in the background. She wears chains around her arms. Above her four portraits of well known freedom fighters are shown: ???, Tilak, ??? and Bose (from left to right).

text-en: 1941 October 1941

description-en: On this image, the figure of female person, also known as Bharat Mata or Mother India holding a tricolour flag and standing on the southern peak of the subcontinent can be seen as well as four heads in the background. She wears chains around her arms. Above her four portraits of well known freedom fighters are shown: ???, Tilak, ??? and Bose (from left to right).
ffff Künstler/Autor: D. Bannerjee [Signatur im Bild]

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The map of India is necessary of course because its presence in her visual persona allows Mother India to be distinguished from the numerous other Hindu goddesses whose calendar art incarnations she otherwise resembles. At the same time, prints like Hind-Mata appear to suggest that it is the mother’s body more than the geo-body of the nation that is important for citizen-viewers to focus upon as they reflect upon this composite image of India as a “carto-graphed” mother/goddess. In the process, borders and boundaries—the very sine qua non of normative state cartography—are transformed to accommodate the mother’s body, in some cases even completely disappearing to allow for the free flow or her saree, her hair or her limbs. (Sumathi Ramaswamy) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The second head from the left is B. Tilak, the one on the right is S. Bose, two reknown freedom-fighters who are also depicted as martyrs and sons of Mother India.
